00022 #include "copynumber/ArrayLevel.h"
00023 //
00024 #include <new>
00025 //
00026 using namespace std;
00027 
00028 // row,col givs the size of the ArrayLevel
00029 ArrayLevel::ArrayLevel(int nrow, int ncol)
00030     {
00031     m_size = make_pair<int,int>(nrow,ncol);
00032     m_array.resize(m_size.first*m_size.second,ArrayElement());
00033 
00034     // Assume the next level will not be made and if incorrect allocate it.
00035     // sz1 and sz2 are computed with the effect of rounding up this array
00036     // to an even number in size.
00037     m_next_level = 0;
00038     if (nrow > 1 && ncol > 1) {
00039         int sz1 = (nrow - 1)/2 + 1;
00040         int sz2 = (ncol - 1)/2 + 1;
00041         m_next_level = new ArrayLevel(sz1,sz2);
00042         }
00043     }
00044 
00045 
00046 // Recursive construction so recursive destruction
00047 ArrayLevel::~ArrayLevel()
00048     {
00049     delete m_next_level;
00050     m_next_level = 0;
00051     }
00052 
00053 
00054 pair<unsigned int,unsigned int> ArrayLevel::size() { return m_size; }
00055 
00056 
00057 // Local phi affects short range smoothing.  Global phi affects long
00058 // range smoothing. Increasing the phis increases their effects.  Increasing
00059 // the phis decreases the local effect of the data.  Convergence terminates
00060 // the method.  An alternative convergence criteria could/should be implemented.
00061 int ArrayLevel::mrf_smooth(double local_phi,double global_phi,double converge)
00062     {
00063     // Always smooth the level above first
00064     if (m_next_level) {
00065         m_next_level->mrf_smooth(local_phi,global_phi,converge);
00066         }
00067 
00068     // beat on the solution until one interation at a time.
00069     int counter = 0;
00070     double this_converge;
00071     do {
00072         counter += 1;
00073         this_converge = mrf_smooth_iter(local_phi,global_phi);
00074         } while (this_converge > converge);
00075 
00076     return counter;
00077     }
00078 
00079 
00080 // This is the heart of the smoothing.  All the other code is plumbing
00081 // to get the data here.
00082 //
00083 // This algorithm is based on a Markov random field.  You need to
00084 // understand a second order neighborhood in a MRF and how MRFs are
00085 // applied to image analysis to understand this algorithm.  Which is
00086 // beyond the scope of comment lines.
00087 
00088 double ArrayLevel::mrf_smooth_iter(double local_phi,double global_phi)
00089     {
00090     double converge = 0.0;
00091     double wt_edge = local_phi*1.0/sqrt(2.0);  // weight in the corners
00092     double wt_corner = local_phi;              // weight along the probes
00093 
00094     for (int i=0; i<m_size.first; i++) {
00095         for (int j=0; j<m_size.second; j++) {
00096             // This is the part where observed data weigh in.
00097             // Grab a reference to save white space.
00098             ArrayElement & AE = m_array[i*m_size.second + j];
00099 
00100             // Proportion of the block loaded with observed values.
00101             double prop = double(AE.count)/double(AE.size);
00102 
00103             // Accumulating a weighted average here.
00104             double total = AE.mean*prop;
00105             double sum_wt = prop;
00106 
00107             // If the next level in the linked lists is there use its
00108             // summary to effect long range smoothing.
00109             if (m_next_level) {
00110                 total += global_phi*(*m_next_level)(i/2,j/2).mean;
00111                 sum_wt += global_phi;
00112                 }
00113 
00114             // average in the neighbors to fill out the clique.  If you
00115             // understand an MRF in the context of image analysis this
00116             // is fairly simple.
00117             for (int row=i-1; row<i+2; row++) {
00118                 if (row<0 || row==m_size.first) continue;
00119                 for (int col=j-1; col<j+2; col++) {
00120                     if (col<0 || col==m_size.second) continue;
00121                     if (row==i && col==j) continue;
00122                     double wt = (row==i || col==j) ? wt_edge : wt_corner;
00123                     total += wt*m_array[row*m_size.second + col].mean;
00124                     sum_wt += wt;
00125                     }
00126                 }
00127 
00128             // A not so elegant use of a relaxation factor.  Not pretty
00129             // but it works.
00130             double old_back = AE.back;
00131             AE.back = total/sum_wt;
00132             double diff = AE.back - old_back;
00133             AE.back += MRF_ITER_RELAX*diff;
00134             diff += MRF_ITER_RELAX*diff;
00135             converge += diff*diff;
00136             }
00137         }
00138 
00139     return converge;
00140     }
00141 
00142 
00143 ArrayElement & ArrayLevel::operator()(int i, int j)
00144     {
00145     return m_array[i*m_size.second + j];
00146     }
00147 
00148 
00149 // Once the data is loaded in at the head of the linked list, the
00150 // 2x2 blocks of data must be aggregated and passed on to the next
00151 // level.  This is how long range smoothing is achieved.  Think
00152 // wavelets if it helps.
00153 void ArrayLevel::load_next_level()
00154     {
00155     // maybe at the end of the list
00156     if (!m_next_level) return;
00157 
00158     // This is all about adding up information in 2x2 arrays, summarising
00159     // it by weight and passing it on.  Also making sure that boundaries
00160     // are not exceeded.
00161     for (int i=0; i<m_next_level->m_size.first; i++) {
00162         for (int j=0; j<m_next_level->m_size.second; j++) {
00163             double mean=0.0;
00164             int count = 0;
00165             int size = 0;
00166             for (int row=2*i; row<2*i + 2; row++) {
00167                 if (row==m_size.first) continue;
00168                 for (int col=2*j; col<2*j + 2; col++) {
00169                     if (col==m_size.second) continue;
00170                     ArrayElement & AE = m_array[row*m_size.second + col];
00171                     size += AE.size;
00172                     if (!AE.count) continue;
00173                     mean += AE.count*AE.mean;
00174                     count += AE.count;
00175                     }
00176                 }
00177 
00178             if (count) mean /= count;
00179             (*m_next_level)(i,j) = ArrayElement(mean,count,size);
00180             }
00181         }
00182 
00183     m_next_level->load_next_level();
00184     }
